gen.conclusions: The proposed antenna design is effective and can be integrated with small satellites for reliable communication. The project brought together engineers from different disciplines and provided valuable knowledge to students about real-world engineering projects (p. 6)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Comparison of simulated and measured results for reflection coefficients, axial ratio, gain, and radiation patterns (p. 4)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Agilent N5227A network analyzer for measurements (p. 4); Satimo StarLab for radiation pattern measurement (p. 4); Numerical modeling using simulation software (p. 6); HFSS 15 for electromagnetic full-wave simulation (p. 4); Environmental and mechanical testing in the KYUTECH Laboratory of Spacecraft Environment Interaction Engineering (LaSEINE) (p. 6)
gen.detailed_methodology.population_cont: HORYU-IV nanosatellite, a 30-cm3 satellite under development at the Kyushu Institute of Technology (p. 2)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Design and simulation of a microstrip patch antenna with asymmetric V-shaped slits and a parasitic strip (pp. 2-3)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The antenna achieved a 7.29 dBi gain at 2.285 GHz (p. 4); The antenna exhibits an effective bandwidth of 2.73% from 2.2450 to 2.3075 GHz for 10-dB return loss and 3-dB AR bandwidth at 13 MHz (p. 6); The impedance and AR bandwidth are sufficient to cover the HORYU-IV S-band communication requirement (p. 4); The 3-dB AR beamwidth is about 1560 at 2.285 GHz (p. 6); The measured gain of the antenna prototype is around 7.29 dBi (p. 6); The 3-dB axial ratio bandwidth was 0.74% (2.278–2.295 GHz) (p. 4)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: Measured parameters show good agreement with the numerical modeling (p. 6); The antenna produces right-hand CP (RHCP) waves in the Z > 0 half-spaces, with a forward RHCP wave 27 dB larger than the backward RHCP wave and 17 dB larger than the backward LHCP (p. 4)
gen.discussion: The design of the CP, high-gain, single-feed, and single-layer S-band patch antenna for small-satellite applications has been successfully presented. The antenna's performance confirms its potential for integration with HORYU-IV small-satellite communications (p. 6)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Measurement | description: Minor soldering imperfections affected the S11 and S22 parameters (p. 5); limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The study is specific to the HORYU-IV project and may not be directly applicable to other satellite designs (p. 6)

gen.objectives.main_objective: To develop a compact, high-gain, circularly polarized microstrip patch antenna for the HORYU-IV nanosatellite S-band communication (p. 1)

gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Traditional satellite communication systems suffer from high costs and large antenna sizes, making them unsuitable for small satellites. Microstrip antennas, while lightweight and low-profile, often have low gain and require circular polarization for orientation-related issues (p. 2)

gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The proposed antenna achieved dual-band bidirectional right-handed circular polarization at 1.575 GHz and 2.230 GHz (p. 3); The cross-polarization ratios were 16 dB for -z-axis at 1.575 GHz and 26 dB for +z-axis at 2.230 GHz (p. 3); The front-to-back radiation ratios were 24 dB for -z-axis at 1.575 GHz and 16 dB for +z-axis at 2.230 GHz (p. 4)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The minimum axial ratios were 2.1 dB for -z-radiation and 1.5 dB for +z-radiation (p. 4); The 3-dB AR bandwidths were 15 MHz for -z direction and 17 MHz for +z direction (p. 4); The measured RHCP gain was -4.55 dBic for backward radiation at 1.578 GHz and 0 dBic for forward radiation at 2.228 GHz (p. 4)
gen.discussion: The proposed antenna design successfully achieved dual-band bidirectional right-handed circular polarization with good agreement between simulation and measurement results, making it a suitable candidate for CubeSat applications (p. 4)

gen.conclusions: The optimized stacked patch antenna design is a lightweight, small-sized, and high-gain communication system suitable for CubeSat applications in the Ka-band. The multiphysics analysis confirms its feasibility and reliability in a LEO environment (p. 12)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm, finite difference time domain (FDTD) simulations, and heat transfer analysis (pp. 4-7)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Finite element analysis (FEA) for thermal and mechanical analysis (p. 2); Comsol Multiphysics for thermal and mechanical analysis (p. 7); CST Microwave Studio for electromagnetic simulations (p. 5); Not mentioned; Simulation software: Altair FEKO (p. 2); PSO algorithm for optimization (p. 9); Comsol for thermal and mechanical analysis (p. 11); Particle swarm optimization algorithm for bandwidth and matching (p. 2)
gen.detailed_methodology.population_cont: CubeSat applications in Low Earth Orbit (LEO) (p. 7)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Multiphysics analysis and particle swarm optimization (pp. 1-2)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: Achieved a bandwidth of 5.53 GHz at 33.185 GHz (p. 1); The optimized antenna design achieved a 10 dB bandwidth of 1 GHz and a return loss better than 10 dB (p. 6); Operational stability from -100 °C to 100 °C with almost constant gain (p. 1); Gain around 8 dB (p. 1); The antenna maintains its pointing direction over the Ka-bands (p. 10); Not mentioned; The thermal analysis showed that the antenna can withstand the thermal conditions of a LEO mission without significant thermal stresses (p. 7); The optimized antenna achieved a bandwidth of 16.6% (p. 10); An 8x8 array of the optimized antenna can achieve a gain of 26 dBi (p. 10)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: Mechanical deformation and stress analysis show negligible impact on antenna performance (p. 1); Not mentioned; The thermal and mechanical stresses are within acceptable limits for the materials used (p. 11); The mechanical analysis indicated that the antenna design is robust against thermal expansion and contraction (p. 7); The antenna's performance is stable over temperature variations (p. 11); Thermal loads can affect antenna matching, but the optimized design mitigates this effect (p. 1)
gen.discussion: The optimized antenna design meets the stringent communication requirements for CubeSat applications in the Ka-band, with a wide bandwidth and stable performance over temperature variations. The thermal and mechanical analysis confirms the feasibility of the design for LEO missions (pp. 11-12)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The study is specific to a 1U CubeSat and may not be directly applicable to other CubeSat sizes or missions (p. 1); limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The study is specific to a sun-synchronous circular orbit at 300 km altitude, and the results may not be directly applicable to other orbits or missions (p. 8); limitation_type: Material properties | description: The use of commercial prepreg and epoxy resins for the antenna assembly may present a risk of failure due to large temperature gradients in extremely cold orbital phases (p. 12); limitation_type: Not mentioned | description: Not mentioned
gen.metadata.keywords: particle swarm optimization; multiphysics; thermal stresses; multiphysics analysis; stacked antenna; Not mentioned; Ka-band; CubeSat; PSO algorithm; stacked patch antenna; optimization; thermal analysis; mechanical analysis

gen.metadata.title: Optimized Design and Multiphysics Analysis of a Ka-Band Stacked Antenna for CubeSat Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and optimize a Ka-band stacked patch antenna for CubeSat applications, and to analyze its thermal and mechanical performance (p. 4)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Perform a multiphysics thermal and mechanical analysis to ensure operational stability (p. 1); Optimize the antenna geometry using a PSO algorithm (p. 8); Achieve a wideband operation and high gain (p. 1); Optimize the antenna design using Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) to achieve maximum bandwidth and return loss (p. 4); Conduct thermal and mechanical analysis to ensure the antenna can withstand the environmental conditions of a LEO mission (p. 7); Perform thermal and mechanical analysis of the antenna in a LEO environment (p. 8); Not mentioned; Evaluate the antenna performance in terms of bandwidth, gain, and radiation pattern (p. 8)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Explore the use of other materials and configurations for further optimization (p. 1); Investigate the performance of the antenna in different orbital environments (p. 1); Investigate the use of other epoxy resins capable of reaching high tensile, shear, and flexural stresses (p. 12); Not mentioned; Explore the optimization of other antenna types for CubeSat applications (p. 8); Investigate the impact of different orbits and mission profiles on antenna performance (p. 8)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the optimized design for future CubeSat missions (p. 1); Use mechanically performing resins or adaptive temperature control strategies to manage thermal and mechanical stresses (p. 12); Conduct further thermal and mechanical testing to validate the simulation results (p. 8); Not mentioned; Implement the optimized antenna design in CubeSat missions (p. 8); Perform similar multiphysics analyses for other CubeSat components (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need to optimize the design of a Ka-band stacked patch antenna for CubeSat applications, considering the unique environmental and thermal conditions of space (p. 4)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a Ka-band stacked patch antenna be designed to meet the multiphysics constraints of CubeSat missions? (p. 1); How can a stacked patch antenna be optimized for CubeSat applications in the Ka-band? (p. 8); What are the thermal and mechanical performance characteristics of the optimized antenna in a LEO environment? (p. 8); How can the antenna design be optimized to meet the operational requirements in Ka-band for CubeSat applications? (p. 4); Not mentioned; What is the impact of thermal and mechanical stresses on the performance of the antenna? (p. 1); What are the thermal and mechanical stresses that the antenna will experience in a LEO mission, and how can they be mitigated? (p. 7)

gen.conclusions: A low-profile S-band CubeSat antenna with broadband CP radiation has been successfully designed and tested. The antenna can be realized with different substrates and is compatible with any CubeSat standard structure (p. 9)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Simulation software (Altair FEKO) (p. 7); Vector network analyzer (Keysight N5244A PNA-X) for impedance measurement (p. 5); ANSYS Electronics Desktop for simulation (p. 2); Anechoic chamber for measurements (p. 8); Tapered anechoic chamber for far-field radiation measurement (p. 5)
gen.detailed_methodology.study_type: Design and performance evaluation of a single-feed slotted-patch antenna loaded with a metasurface (p. 7)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: Achieved an axial ratio < 3 dB bandwidth of 15.23% (1.94-2.26 GHz) (p. 5); The antenna achieved good broadside RHCP radiation with a symmetric profile, high F-B ratio, and high radiation efficiency (p. 8); The proposed antenna achieved a |S11| < −10 dB bandwidth of 24.64% (1.85-2.37 GHz) (p. 8); The broadside realized gain was 5.6 to 6.7 dBic (p. 8); Achieved a broadside realized gain of 5.6 to 6.7 dBic (p. 5); Achieved a |S11| < −10 dB bandwidth of 24.64% (1.85-2.37 GHz) (p. 5); The axial ratio (AR) < 3 dB bandwidth was 15.23% (1.94-2.26 GHz) (p. 8)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: Good broadside right-hand circularly polarized (RHCP) radiation with symmetric pattern, high front-to-back ratio, and high radiation efficiency (p. 1); The estimated measured radiation efficiency was >70% (p. 8); The HPBWs were 72° and 64° at 2.0 GHz, and 64° and 66° at 2.22 GHz (p. 8); The measured F-B ratio was 19.0 dB at 2.0 GHz and 17.0 dB at 2.22 GHz (p. 8)
gen.discussion: The proposed antenna design offers a low-profile, broadband, and circularly polarized solution for CubeSat applications, with advantages of simple configuration, stable radiation, and easy fabrication (p. 9)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Radiation efficiency | description: The antenna design on low-cost FR4 substrate suffers a radiation efficiency of 74% to 79% (p. 5); limitation_type: Measurement limitations | description: The measured radiation efficiency could not be directly measured due to the function limitation of the anechoic chamber (p. 8)

gen.conclusions: The proposed high-gain, circularly polarized X-band microstrip patch antenna design meets the requirements for CubeSat applications. Future work will focus on increasing the gain further by studying different EBG and metamaterial topologies (p. 16)

gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Helical antennas for circular polarization qualification (p. 13); Time-domain solver for simulation (p. 6); Not mentioned; Anechoic chamber for far-field radiation pattern measurement (p. 12); CST Studio Suite 2019 for full-wave electromagnetic simulations (p. 6); Vector Network Analyzer (VNA) for return loss measurement (p. 11)

gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The 3 dB axial ratio bandwidth is approximately 250 MHz (p. 16); Not mentioned; Measured axial ratio (AR) of around 1.4 dB at 8.483 GHz (p. 1); Measured gain of around 11.7 dBi at 8.483 GHz (p. 1); The antenna gain is around 11.72 dBi at 8.483 GHz (p. 16); The spatial axial ratio is about 1.4 dB at 8.483 GHz (p. 16)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The measured −10 dB operational bandwidth is around 900 MHz (p. 13); The EBG ring significantly enhances the antenna gain and circular polarization (p. 1); The antenna efficiency is 95% (p. 15); Not mentioned; The measured far-field radiation patterns have good agreement with the simulation results (p. 14)
gen.discussion: The proposed design achieves a significant gain enhancement without increasing the total height of the antenna structure, making it suitable for CubeSat platforms. The low profile and simple design ensure compatibility and robustness (p. 16)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Design complexity | description: The design must fit within the 10 cm × 10 cm surface area and 6.5 mm height constraint of a 3U CubeSat (p. 5); limitation_type: Manufacturing | description: Discrepancies in the antenna manufacturing process can affect the measured return loss values (p. 13); limitation_type: Structural Robustness | description: The use of 16 soldering nodes to fix the connecting vias to the EBG elements and the ground can be considered a drawback (p. 12); limitation_type: Not mentioned | description: Not mentioned

gen.metadata.title: Design of a High-Gain X-Band Electromagnetic Band Gap Microstrip Patch Antenna for CubeSat Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a high-gain, circularly polarized X-band microstrip patch antenna (MPA) using an electromagnetic band gap (EBG) structure for CubeSat applications (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Ensure the antenna fits within the 10 cm × 10 cm surface area of a 3U CubeSat (p. 1); Evaluate the antenna performance with 3U CubeSat platforms (p. 16); Achieve gain enhancement using a 16-element ring of EBG structures (p. 16); Form right-hand circular polarization by etching two square slots symmetrically along the right diagonal line of the center radiator (p. 16); Integrate a single EBG ring around a single-element MPA to enhance gain and circular polarization (p. 1); Not mentioned; Maintain a simple and robust design to ensure compatibility with CubeSat standards (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Not mentioned; Investigation of other EBG structures and their impact on antenna performance (p. 1); Study different EBG and metamaterial topologies to further increase the gain (p. 16)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Not mentioned; Use the proposed antenna design for CubeSat applications (p. 16); Further testing and validation in real CubeSat missions (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Designing a high-gain, circularly polarized X-band microstrip patch antenna (MPA) for CubeSat applications, while maintaining simplicity and robustness (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: What is the impact of electromagnetic band-gap (EBG) structures on the antenna's performance? (p. 16); How can the gain of a microstrip patch antenna be enhanced for CubeSat applications? (p. 16); Not mentioned; How can an electromagnetic band gap (EBG) structure be integrated into a single-element MPA to enhance gain and circular polarization while fitting within the size and weight constraints of a CubeSat? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: Anechoic chamber with a pair of X-band helical antennas (p. 12)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Time-domain solver in CST Studio Suite 2019 (p. 6)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms other designs in terms of gain, axial ratio, and bandwidth while maintaining a low profile and simple design (p. 15)
esp.domain_results.return_loss: −21.9 dB (original MPA), −18.2 dB (CP EBG MPA) at 8.483 GHz (p. 6)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_dim: 10 mm × 10 mm (center patch radiator), 10 mm × 10 mm (EBG elements), 2 mm spacing (p. 5)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_siz: Fits within 10 cm × 10 cm surface area of a 3U CubeSat (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: High-gain X-band electromagnetic band gap microstrip patch antenna (p. 1)

gen.conclusions: The high gain CP microstrip patch antenna array for X-band CubeSat applications achieves a high LHCP gain of 20.1 dB at 10.4 GHz with good cross-polar isolation and broad bandwidth, making it suitable for high-data rate downlink communications (p. 5)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Simulation results and performance metrics analysis (p. 3)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: HFSS for full wave simulation (p. 3); Far-field performance analysis (p. 4)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Design and simulation of a high gain, circularly polarized microstrip patch antenna array (p. 1)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The 36-element antenna array achieves a high LHCP gain of 20.1 dB at 10.4 GHz with good cross-polar isolation of -18 dB (p. 4); The array presents a -3 dB AR bandwidth of 3.8% and a -10 dB impedance bandwidth of 21% (p. 4); The -3 dB gain bandwidth of the array is 38.4%, maintaining high gain performance over the X-band (p. 5)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The presence of the CubeSat body increases the cross-polar components by 7 dB in the principal planes, but they remain below -18 dB (p. 4); The side lobe levels (SLLs) in the principal planes stay below -14 dB from the maximum gain (p. 4)
gen.discussion: The proposed high gain CP microstrip patch antenna array is suitable for high-data rate downlink CubeSat communications, greatly expanding the current CubeSat capabilities (p. 5)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Simulation | description: The study is based on simulation results and does not include experimental validation (p. 5)
gen.metadata.keywords: CubeSat; Antenna Array; Circular Polarization; X-band; High Data Rate
gen.metadata.authors: Panagiotis Ioannis Theoharis; Suhila Abulgasem; Raad Raad; Faisel Tubbal
gen.metadata.title: High-Gain Circular Polarized Microstrip Patch Array for X-band CubeSat Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and optimize a high gain, left-hand circularly polarized (LHCP) microstrip patch antenna array for X-band CubeSat applications (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Design and optimize a single element CP patch antenna (p. 2); Develop a 36-element antenna array based on the optimized CP patch element (p. 3); Evaluate the performance of the array with and without the CubeSat body (p. 3)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Conduct experimental validation of the proposed antenna array (p. 5)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Integrate the proposed antenna array in CubeSat designs for high-data rate downlink communications (p. 5)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Low data rate capabilities of CubeSats and the need for high gain, circularly polarized antennas to ensure reliable up/downlink communication (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can high gain, circularly polarized microstrip patch antenna arrays be designed for X-band CubeSat applications? (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_siz: 90% of a 1U CubeSat's bottom face (100 × 100 mm²) (p. 4)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: High-gain circularly polarized microstrip patch array (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: CP single-feed square patch with truncated corners (p. 2)
L = 6 mm, SL = 1.68 mm, SW = 1.79 mm, Px = 1.6 mm, Py = 0.48 mm (p. 2)

gen.conclusions: The S-band patch antenna with circular polarization is suitable for CubeSat communication systems, providing high gain and good impedance matching (p. 4)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Simulation results analyzed for gain, return loss, and radiation pattern (p. 3)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Design and simulation of a patch antenna using CST software (p. 2)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The antenna provides a maximum gain of 8.17 dBi at 0 degrees (p. 3); The main lobe is at 73.7 degrees and the side lobe is -22.1 dBi (p. 3); When installed on the CubeSat, the antenna gain is 8.8 dBi, the propagation angle is 60.1 degrees, and the side lobe value is -12.2 dBi (p. 4)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The antenna has a bandwidth of 120 MHz and a directional radiation pattern (p. 3)
gen.discussion: The proposed antenna design meets the requirements for CubeSat communication systems, providing high gain and circular polarization (p. 4)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Simulation | description: The results are based on simulation and may differ from actual performance (p. 4)
gen.metadata.keywords: S-band; CubeSat; planar monopole antenna; circular polarization
gen.metadata.authors: N. Thunyakaset; S. Ratanacharoen; A. Namsang; R. Lerdwanittip; P. Chomtong; P. Akkaraekthalin
gen.metadata.title: Design of S-band CubeSat Antenna
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design an S-band patch antenna with circular polarization suitable for CubeSat communication systems (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve a resonance frequency of 2.4 GHz-2.45 GHz (p. 2); Achieve a bandwidth of 50 MHz (p. 2); Achieve a directional radiation pattern with a main lobe of 70 degrees (p. 2); Ensure a return loss better than 10 dBi and an antenna gain more than 0 dBi at 0 degrees (p. 2)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigation of the antenna's performance under different environmental conditions (p. 4)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Further testing and validation of the antenna design in real-world CubeSat applications (p. 4)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for a compact, high-gain, circularly polarized S-band patch antenna for CubeSat communication systems (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a patch antenna be designed to achieve circular polarization and high gain for CubeSat applications? (p. 1)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Directional with a main lobe of 73.7 degrees and a side lobe of -22.1 dBi (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Single-feed patch antenna with truncated corners (p. 2)
